hi

I was asked a very good question regarding my choice to invest in Blackrock. The question was: if you believe in the power of investing in ETFs, in other words, the potential of gaining wealth by owning a basket of stocks or bonds or individual commodities, why would you invest in a single stock (BLK) and not practice what you preach and put your money on any of the ETPs?My answer is simple, I don’t proclaim to be smart enough to know which investment vehicle will outperform in the next year or two. In the long term I believe precious metals will be much higher, Gold might even be worth more than $100,000, other commodities like oil will also be higher, stocks will be higher too. The point is that, to me, all these investments will be higher and although I am not sure which ones will outperform the other, the one thing I know for sure is that the medium in which these investments will be accessed will overwhelmingly be through ETPs.Sure, I can purchase the Gold, Oil, S&P, Nasdaq and all other major index products domestic or foreign out there. But isn’t it better to own the “miner” of these investments? If Blackrock was not a public traded company, I guess I would definitely purchase the 5 or 10 or 20 different ETF’s in my portfolio too. And I am sure much smarter professionals and more daring than me, will choose to bet on specific markets to do better than others. They might even be smart enough to invest in leveraged ETFs to enhance their returns. However, the fact still remains that one of the few alternatives out there to owning anything other than ETPs and not individual stocks, is Blackrock. The issuer of ETPs. The only other few choices out there other than ETPs are the index providers like CME and trading platforms like Schwab and also perhaps payment platforms like Mastercard or Paypal.

So a few thoughts that make me worried. Large Asset managers are chasing flow growth at any price and seeking to grow in less liquid or private markets as there is less transparency and so the asset manager keeps some pricing power. There is way too much money chasing this. So what happens when inflation and interest rates ( which are real impacts on people ) both go up or borrowing gets harder. I think the drive for more flow from global ETF providers is the source of the next downturn but it won’t be the ETF it will be another department that was tasked with fee growth to compensate for the flow drive

My equal weight FAANG stock portfolio has done exceptionally well YTD, up 40% TR vs 4.5% TR for the S&P. The question now is: does one hold on to the FAANG stocks or will there be a better alternative sector going forward? And if so, which 5 stocks within that sector would you invest in? My answer to all of the above is, I believe the below five stocks will be the top performers of the S&P for the next six months (I refer to the picks as BPMCS):BLACKROCK $BLKPAYPAL $PYPLMASTERCARD $MACME GROUP $CMECHARLES SCHWAB $SCHWBPMCS stocks might have performed 15% YTD vs 40% of the FAANG stocks, BPMCS has however, half the forward P/E multiple than FAANG and almost double the ROE.Again, I’m not predicting that FAANG will do poorly from now on, all I’m prognosticating is that BPMCS will be the top 5 performing stocks in the S&P from now till the end of the year.AP
